security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing implementation guides and TypeScript code examples for AgentDB memory management. No executable code, network calls, or file system access. Static findings are false positives from pattern-matching scanner misinterpreting documentation text as security threats.

content.user_title: Build AI Agent Memory Systems with AgentDB
content.value_statement: AI agents forget everything between sessions. This skill shows you how to build persistent memory systems using AgentDB, enabling your agents to remember conversations, learn patterns, and maintain context across interactions.
actual_capabilities: Implement session memory with TTL management
Optimize memory retrieval for sub-50ms performance
limitations: Requires AgentDB database setup and configuration
Basic TypeScript or JavaScript knowledge needed
Memory capacity depends on AgentDB configuration

use_cases.title: Learning Agents

prompt_templates.title: Memory Architecture Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me design a memory architecture for my AI agent using AgentDB. I need episodic memory for conversations, semantic memory for facts, and procedural memory for learned skills.

prompt_templates.title: Session Memory Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to implement session memory in AgentDB that stores conversation history and expires after 24 hours of inactivity.

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Learning Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: I want my agent to learn from user interactions. How do I implement pattern learning with clustering in AgentDB?

prompt_templates.title: Memory Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: My agent memory queries are slow. Help me optimize retrieval speed with caching and indexing in AgentDB.

output_examples.input: How do I store user preferences in AgentDB memory?
output: Create episodic memory store with 768-dimensional embeddings
Store preference with embedding: 'User prefers dark theme'
Set TTL for 24-hour persistence with time-based consolidation
Retrieve with similarity search on 'user preferences' query

output_examples.input: Set up long-term memory for my customer support agent
output: Design 3-layer memory: episodic for conversations, semantic for knowledge, procedural for resolution patterns
Configure importance-based consolidation to preserve valuable insights
Implement HNSW indexing for fast similarity search across millions of memories
Add caching layer to reduce latency for frequently accessed memories

best_practices: Use appropriate memory types: episodic for events, semantic for facts, procedural for skills
Implement TTL-based expiration to manage memory size and relevance
Test memory retrieval performance with realistic data volumes before deployment
anti_patterns: Storing all data as single memory type reduces retrieval accuracy and relevance
Skipping memory consolidation leads to unbounded storage growth over time
Hardcoding memory limits prevents scalability and dynamic resource allocation

faq.question: Is this compatible with all AgentDB versions?
faq.answer: Works with AgentDB 2.0 and later versions with memory extension enabled

faq.question: What is the maximum memory size?
faq.answer: Limited by your AgentDB configuration, typically supports millions of vectors

faq.question: Can I integrate with existing databases?
faq.answer: Yes, AgentDB supports hybrid storage combining vector and traditional databases

faq.question: Is user data secure in memory?
faq.answer: AgentDB provides encryption at rest and in transit for sensitive data

faq.question: What if memory retrieval is slow?
faq.answer: Use HNSW indexing and caching layers to achieve sub-50ms retrieval times

faq.question: How does this compare to Redis or MongoDB?
faq.answer: AgentDB combines vector similarity search with traditional storage optimized for AI memory patterns
